answers.answer: Low testosterone in men occcurs during andropause which is the same as menopause for women.  They get moody, hot flashes and brittle bones due to low testosterone.  He is a Type II diabetic, but none of his doctors have said anything about his testosterone playing a role in that.  I'm happy you are feeling better, and yes, we often need to take things into our own hands,  Good for you!

question: From August, my blood sugars started to go wildly out of control...even though I inject Apidra and Lantus with 3x Simlyn daily.  Nothing had changed in my diet but I had awful PMS symptoms at age 61.  Finally, before my next round of quarterly lab tests, I stopped by my Endo's office and asked if he'd add a hormone panel--because something wasn't right and I reminded him I was in diabetes because of PCOS (and it manifest in liver).  OMG, it pays to be self-directed...not only did the tests show I was again short of thyroid and moved up to 7.5 Synthorid but I literally had NO ESTROGEN in my body, ie the 494 glucose readings in the evening!  I went on HRT and felt better in 3 days...and like a new woman 20 days later!  And I heard men need to have testosterone tested because their BSs can go crazy when that is out of balance.  I'm also taking 5000 IUs of D3 daily and I will be tested for testosterone, too.  We need to get the word out...male and female hormones MATTER in diabetes!  Any input?
title: PCOS & Type 2:  No estrogen=High BS!!!!
